awd_titl_txt: Vp/Vs Structure of the Crust and Reflection Fabric of the Upper Mantle beneath the Southern Appalachians using Teleseismic and Global Phases
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this work is to gain a better understanding of the deep geologic structure of the southeastern U.S., from the Appalachian Mountains to the coast. By using seismic waves generated by distant earthquakes the investigators are able to conduct echo soundings of the Earth's crust and mantle to a depth of 300 km (180 miles).  The methodology is adapted in part from exploration techniques used by the petroleum industry. The results from this work, when added to parallel analyses by other researchers, will allow the construction of a three-dimensional model of the subsurface.  This model will help us to unravel the sequence of geologic events that led to the formation of the Appalachian mountains and adjacent terrain and the mineral resources found there.   The research will provide financial support and valuable technical training for graduate students pursuing careers in the geosciences.  The grant will also provide valuable research experience for undergraduate students and will support our ongoing education/outreach program for students in grades 4-6.  As of October 2017, the principal investigator had worked with over 2150 elementary and middle-school students (in groups of 15-20 at a time) in outdoor, hands-on exercises in plate tectonics and seismology.  The current plan is to expand those activities to additional school districts across the state of Georgia.


The passage of USArray across the eastern United States has resulted in fundamentally new insights into the fine-scale structure of the continental lithosphere and has helped to rekindle interest in old mountain belts.  The proposed work will use a combination of body waves (Ps, SsPmp, PpPmp. and reflections generated by PKIKP/PKiKP) to enhance our images of the crust and upper mantle across a portion of the southern Appalachians, beneath stations of the SESAME array.  The goal of this work is to address the following questions: 1) Can more reliable estimates of average crustal Vp/Vs be obtained across the Atlantic Coastal Plain, where reverberations within very low-velocity sediments tend to overwhelm Ps conversions from the Moho, and what do those values of Vp/Vs tell us about the degree to which the basement in this highly extended region was modified by mafic intrusions during Mesozoic rifting? 2) Are there fundamental differences in small-wavelength reflection fabric that might be used to distinguish lithosphere from asthenosphere? 3) Does strain in the lithosphere occur as distributed shear, or is it typically localized along well-defined shear zones? 4) Can we distinguish between different flow patterns in the mantle - e.g., vertical versus horizontal flow, and if so, can we improve on the vertical resolving power of SKS/PKS/SKKS arrivals to place stronger constraints on depth ranges responsible for observations of shear-wave splitting? Improved estimates of Vp/Vs will be obtained by first constructing localized models of crustal thickness and average crustal P-wave velocity using SsPmp and PpPmp arrivals. The resulting set of localized estimates of crustal thickness and average crustal P-wave velocity will be used to help constrain the grid search for Vp/Vs for stations deployed in the Coastal Plain. For the upper mantle, we will use the global seismic phase PKIKP (PKPdf) as a virtual source to construct normal-incidence reflection sections that are analogous to those produced by active-source reflection profiling of the crust.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
We used seismic P-waves generated by distant earthquakes to conduct echo soundings of deep geologic structure beneath the United States.  Our main goals were to investigate the deep structure of the Appalachian Mountains, determine the thickness of the underlying tectonic plate, and investigate the nature of flow within less rigid material beneath the plate. The work was carried out in two main stages: 1) follow-up analysis of data recorded by the "SESAME" array, and 2) application of protocols developed in that study for the analysis of data recorded by the "Transportable Array" or "TA".  

 

"SESAME" (Southeastern Suture of the Appalachian Margin Experiment) consisted of 85 broadband seismograph stations deployed by UGA, Brown University, and University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill from 2010 to 2014 across the southern Appalachians and adjacent Piedmont and Atlantic Coastal Plain.  Deployments lasted from two to four years, and would not have been possible without the generosity and enthusiasm of private landowners, private businesses, and state park officials across Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, and Florida.  We thank them for their support.  Results from work sponsored by the present grant, published in a paper by Verellen et al. (2020), include the mapping of a major transition at depths of 120-135 km that we interpret as drag-induced flow just beneath the North American tectonic plate. We also see a pronounced thickening of Earth's crust beneath the highest elevations of the southern Appalachians that suggests that these very old mountains are in gravitational equilibrium.

 

The "TA" was a much larger array of broadband stations that moved as a grid (station spacing: 70 km) across the nation from 2004 to 2014.   We used a subset of stations from 15 east-west profiles to extend our previous work north along the central Appalachians and west across the continental interior, to just west of the Mississippi River.  Results from this work, most recently presented by Hanawalt et al. [2022], show a significant increase in the number and continuity of reflections from layering at depths greater than 130 km, supporting the interpretation of drag-induced flow produced by westward motion of the overlying plate.  We also see a northward extension of crustal thickening beneath the central Appalachians.

 

This grant supported 4 graduate and 3 undergraduate students.  Funds were used for graduate student stipends, travel to regional meetings, and purchase of storage media for archiving data.

 

References

 

Publications (others are in preparation):

 

Verellen, D. N., E. C. Alberts, G. A. Larramendi, E. H. Parker, and R. B. Hawman (2020), P-wave reflectivity of the crust and upper mantle beneath the Southern Appalachians and Atlantic Coastal Plain using global phases, Geophys. Res. Lett., 47, e2020GL089648, https://doi.org/10.1029/2020GL089648.

 

 

Presentations at Meetings:

 

Hanawalt, L. E., M. P. Cuilik, and R. B. Hawman (2022). Mountain roots, lithospheric layering, and mantle flow: Imaging P-wave reflectivity beneath the eastern U.S., Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs, Vol. 54, No. 4, doi:10.1130/abs/2022NC-374486. 

Hanawalt, L. E., M. P. Cuilik, R. S. Hufstetler, and R. B. Hawman (2021). Structure of the lithosphere across the Appalachian Orogen: Reflection profiling using earthquakes, Southeastern Section of the Geological Society of America, Annual Meeting, Auburn, AL, April 1, 2021. 

Clements, A. G., G. A. Larramendi, and R. B. Hawman (2019). Investigating rift basins and underlying crust beneath the southeastern Atlantic coastal plain using teleseismic phases recorded by the SESAME broadband array, Southeastern Section of the Geological Society of America, Annual Meeting, Charleston, SC, March 28-29, 2019.

Larramendi, G. A., A. G. Clements, and R. B. Hawman (2019). Investigation of the late Paleozoic collision in southern Georgia between Gondwana and Laurentia and the resulting deformational response of the upper mantle, Southeastern Section of the Geological Society of America, Annual Meeting, Charleston, SC, March 28-29, 2019.

Rice, T. A., H. E. Luke, and R. B. Hawman (2019). Wide-angle reflection mapping and P-wave velocity analysis of the South Georgia Basin and root of the Appalachian Mountains, Southeastern Section of the Geological Society of America, Annual Meeting, Charleston, SC, March 28-29, 2019.

Rice, T. A. (2019). The resilience of Appalachian topography: A geophysical analysis of the root structure of the southern Appalachians, CURO (Center for Undergraduate Research Opportunities) Symposium, University of Georgia, April 8, 2019. 

 

Graduate Theses:

 

Cuilik, M. P. (2022). High-resolution mapping of lithospheric discontinuities between the eastern continental margin and interior of the North American continent using PKIKP as a virtual seismic source, M.S. thesis, University of Georgia, Athens, GA (available after August 2022).

Larramendi, G. A. (2020). Investigation of the late Paleozoic collision between Gondwana and Laurentia and the resulting deformational response of the upper mantle beneath the southern Appalachians using global phase seismic events, M.S. thesis, University of Georgia, Athens, GA. 

Clements, A. G. (2019). Investigation of rift basins and underlying crust beneath the southeastern Atlantic coastal plain using teleseismic phases, M.S. thesis, University of Georgia, Athens, GA.

We used seismic P-waves generated by distant earthquakes to conduct echo soundings of deep geologic structure beneath the United States.  Our main goals were to investigate the deep structure of the Appalachian Mountains, determine the thickness of the underlying tectonic plate, and investigate the nature of flow within less rigid material beneath the plate. The work was carried out in two main stages: 1) follow-up analysis of data recorded by the "SESAME" array, and 2) application of protocols developed in that study for the analysis of data recorded by the "Transportable Array" or "TA".

Deployments lasted from two to four years, and would not have been possible without the generosity and enthusiasm of private landowners, private businesses, and state park officials across Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, and Florida.  We thank them for their support.  Results from work sponsored by the present grant, published in a paper by Verellen et al. (2020), include the mapping of a major transition at depths of 120-135 km that we interpret as drag-induced flow just beneath the North American tectonic plate. We also see a pronounced thickening of Earth's crust beneath the highest elevations of the southern Appalachians that suggests that these very old mountains are in gravitational equilibrium.

We used a subset of stations from 15 east-west profiles to extend our previous work north along the central Appalachians and west across the continental interior, to just west of the Mississippi River.  Results from this work, most recently presented by Hanawalt et al. [2022], show a significant increase in the number and continuity of reflections from layering at depths greater than 130 km, supporting the interpretation of drag-induced flow produced by westward motion of the overlying plate.  We also see a northward extension of crustal thickening beneath the central Appalachians.

 

This grant supported 4 graduate and 3 undergraduate students.  Funds were used for graduate student stipends, travel to regional meetings, and purchase of storage media for archiving data.
